{{TOC left}} {{clear}} <!-- Avoid layout clash between sidebar and July table. Eventually a longer lead section will help fill the empty space. --> {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}}
==Overview== === Public opinion === According to [[FiveThirtyEight]], President Trump's approval rate at the end of March was 40.5%, up 2% from the previous quarter and down 4.9% from the start of his presidency.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings |title=How unpopular is Donald Trump? |website=projects.fivethirtyeight.com |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170616000621/https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/ |archivedate=June 16, 2017 |df=mdy-all}}</ref>
== Timeline == === January 2018 ===
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Events ! Photos |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 50 ==== |- | Monday, '''January 1''' | *The Trump administration announces it will withhold the scheduled millions of military aid to [[Pakistan]] with President Trump declaring it a terrorist 'safe haven'.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/01/trump-withholding-millions-in-aid-to-pakistan-as-accuses-country-giving-safe-haven-to-terrorists.html |title=Trump withholding millions in aid to Pakistan, as he accuses country of giving 'safe haven' to terrorists |work=Fox News |date=January 1, 2018}}</ref> *[[Nick Ayers]] announces that [[Mike Pence|Vice President Mike Pence's]] chief lawyer, [[Mark Paoletta]], and domestic policy director, [[Daris Meeks]], are to resign.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/05/politics/mike-pence-staff-departures/index.html |title=Top Pence aides quietly depart in new year |date=January 6, 2017 |publisher=CNN}}</ref> | |- | Tuesday, '''January 2''' | *President Trump tweets that his "[[nuclear button]]" is larger and more powerful than that of [[Kim Jong-un]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2018/01/02/trump-sounds-open-to-korea-dialogue-then-mocks-kim-jong-un.html |title=Trump boasts of bigger 'nuclear button' than North Korea's |date=January 2, 2017 |publisher=Fox News}}</ref> *On [[Twitter]], President Trump refers to the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] as the [[deep state in the United States|'deep state']] and then calls on it to investigate former [[Director of the FBI|FBI director]] [[James Comey]] and Hillary Clinton's top aide, [[Huma Abedin]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/02/jail-trump-slams-crooked-hillary-aide-huma-calls-on-deep-state-doj-to-act.html |title='Jail!' Trump slams 'crooked' Hillary aide Huma, calls on 'Deep State' DOJ to act |work=Fox News |date=January 2, 2018}}</ref> *Via Twitter, President Trump threatens to cut off US aid to the [[Palestinian Authority]], claiming the Palestinians were no longer willing to negotiate on a peace process with the Israelis - seemingly after his December 2017 decision to recognize [[Jerusalem]] as the capital of [[Israel]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://apnews.com/014efbb86511429d9c09c818a76f58e0/Trump-threatens-to-cut-off-US-aid-to-Palestinian-Authority |title=Trump threatens to cut off US aid to Palestinian Authority |agency=Associated Press |date=January 2, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''January 3''' | *President Trump disbands his Presidential Advisory Commission on Election Integrity.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-42561699 |title=Trump scraps his own voter fraud commission |date=January 4, 2017 |publisher=BBC}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/i-was-on-trumps-voter-fraud-commission-its-demise-was-inevitable/2018/01/07/b5c1bec8-f261-11e7-97bf-bba379b809ab_story.html |title=I was on Trump's voter fraud commission. Its demise was inevitable. |date=January 7, 2017 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref> *President Trump issues a statement describing [[Steve Bannon]], former CEO of the Trump campaign, as having "very little to do with our historic victory" and as having "lost his mind", following the publication of excerpts from a forthcoming book by [[Michael Wolff (journalist)|Michael Wolff]] in which Bannon is said to describe [[Donald Trump Jr]], [[Paul Manafort]] and [[Jared Kushner|Jared Kushner's]] [[Trump campaign–Russian meetings#Trump Tower meeting, June 9, 2016|meeting with Natalia Veselnitskaya]] as "treasonous" and "unpatriotic". Wolff's book also describes Bannon's confidence that Trump Sr knew of the meeting at the time.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/bannon-trump-book-russia-claims-bad-news-president-cost-dearly-a8140691.html |title=Trump trusted Bannon the most, and that could now cost him very dearly |date=January 3, 2017 |publisher=The Independent}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/steve-bannon-calls-trump-tower-russian-meeting-treasonous-new-book-n834286 |title=Steve Bannon calls Trump Tower Russian meeting 'treasonous' in new book |date=January 3, 2017 |publisher=NBC News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/01/steve-bannon-is-trumps-frankenstein-monster/549566/ |title=Steve Bannon Comes Back to Haunt Donald Trump |date=January 3, 2017 |publisher=The Atlantic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://nypost.com/2018/01/03/bannon-trump-jr-meeting-with-russians-was-treasonous/ |title=Bannon: Trump Jr. meeting with Russians was 'treasonous' |date=January 3, 2017 |publisher=The New York Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/03/donald-trump-russia-steve-bannon-michael-wolff |title=Trump Tower meeting with Russians 'treasonous', Bannon says in explosive book |date=January 3, 2017 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> | |- | Thursday, '''January 4''' | *President Trump's lawyer [[Charles Harder|Charles J. Harder]] sends to Michael Wolff and his publisher, [[Henry Holt and Company]], a [[Cease and desist|cease and desist letter]] demanding the non-publication of Wolff's White House exposé, [[Fire and Fury (book)|''Fire and Fury'']], due for release on January 9.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-slams-bannon-when-he-was-fired-he-not-only-lost-his-job-he-lost-his-mind/2018/01/03/21fb158a-f0aa-11e7-b3bf-ab90a706e175_story.html |title=Trump lawyer seeks to block insider book on White House |date=January 4, 2017 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/01/michael-wolff-fire-and-fury-book-donald-trump.html |title=Donald Trump Didn't Want to Be President |date=January 3, 2017 |publisher=New York Magazine}}</ref> Wolff's publishers move the date of publication forward to January 5.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/04/trump-lawyers-book-steve-bannon-white-house |title=Tell-all book on Trump to be released early despite White House legal effort |date=January 4, 2017 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> *[[Ryan Zinke|Secretary of the Interior Ryan Zinke]] announces a plan to open up 90% of the U.S. coastline to oil drilling.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/jan/04/trump-administration-plans-to-allow-oil-and-gas-drilling-off-nearly-all-us-coast |title=Trump administration plans to allow oil and gas drilling off nearly all US coast |date=January 4, 2017 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''January 5''' | *The Trump administration submits to Congress initial details of a request for $18bn to fund 316 miles of new barriers and upgrades to [[Mexico–United States barrier|407 miles of existing barriers along the Mexican border]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/05/donald-trump-mexico-border-wall-congress-18-billion |title=Trump administration seeks $18bn from Congress for Mexico border wall |date=January 6, 2017 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> *Wolff's [[Fire and Fury (book)|''Fire and Fury'']] is published. President Trump describes it on Twitter as a "phony book", "full of lies, misrepresentations and sources that don't exist".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/05/trump-tweets-explosive-white-house-tell-all-full-lies.html |title=Trump tweets explosive White House tell-all 'full of lies' |date=January 5, 2017 |publisher=Fox News}}</ref> *[[Bureau of Safety and Environmental Enforcement|BSEE]] Director [[Scott Angelle]] announces plans to overhaul the oil-industry regulations introduced following 2010's [[Deepwater Horizon|Deepwater Horizon disaster]]<ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/trump-overturns-oil-safety-rules-brought-deepwater-horizon-121815040.html |title=Trump overturns oil safety rules brought in after Deepwater Horizon |date=January 5, 2017 |publisher=Yahoo News}}</ref> *President Trump leaves for [[Camp David]] for a weekend of meetings with his Cabinet, Republican party leaders, and Vice President Pence. It is reported that a decision is expected concerning whether the administration will move next to welfare reform or infrastructure.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-hosts-camp-david-retreat-this-weekend-for-gop-leaders-cabinet/ |title=Trump hosts Camp David retreat this weekend for GOP leaders, Cabinet |date=January 5, 2017 |publisher=CBS News}}</ref> *NSA Director [[Michael S. Rogers]] announces his retirement for spring 2018.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/nsa-director-mike-rogers-retirement-2018-1?r=US&IR=T |title=NSA director Mike Rogers announces his retirement |date=January 5, 2017 |publisher=Business Insider}}</ref> *Following a personal interview with President Trump, former [[Deutsche Bank]] lawyer [[Geoffrey Berman]] takes up his position as interim U.S. attorney for the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of New York|Southern District of New York]]. Berman shortly afterwards appoints as his deputy Deutsche Bank's former U.S. general counsel [[Robert Khuzami]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/interim-us-attorney-apos-interview-104713945.html |title=New Interim US Attorney's Interview With Trump 'Disqualifying': NY Senator |date=January 8, 2017 |publisher=Yahoo News/Law.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-10/deutsche-bank-ties-may-spur-recusals-by-new-u-s-attorneys |title=Deutsche Bank Ties May Spur Recusals by New U.S. Attorneys |date=January 10, 2017 |publisher=Bloomberg}}</ref> | |- |Saturday, '''January 6''' | *President Trump tweets that he is a "very stable genius", praising his own "mental stability". Also within the tweet, he says that he became president "on the first try",<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/06/politics/donald-trump-white-house-fitness-very-stable-genius/index.html |title=Trump: I'm a 'very stable genius' |last=CNN |first=Daniella Diaz, |work=CNN|access-date=January 6, 2018}}</ref> despite having [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2000|run]] as a [[Reform Party of the United States of America|Reform Party]] candidate in 2000.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Helmore |first1=Edward |title=How Trump’s political playbook evolved since he first ran for president in 2000 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/feb/05/donald-trump-reform-party-2000-president |work=The Guardian |accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> *President Trump declares that "everyone found that, after a year of study, there's been absolutely no collusion ... between us and the Russians." Meanwhile, the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|special counsel investigation]] into such matters are still in progress with no declared findings.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Woodward |first1=Calvin |last2=Lowy |first2=Joan |title=AP Fact Check: Trump says collusion is disproved; it's not |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/wireStory/ap-fact-check-trump-collusion-disproved-52204398 |agency=Associated Press}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 51 ==== |- | Monday, '''January 8''' | *President Trump makes an on-field appearance during the National Anthem at the 2018 College Football Playoff National Championship.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.si.com/college-football/2018/01/08/donald-trump-2018-college-football-national-championship-game-national-anthem |title=Watch: President Donald Trump On Field For National Anthem At National Championship Game |last=Chavez |first=Chris |date=January 8, 2018 |work=Sports Illustrated|access-date=January 30, 2018}}</ref> *The Trump administration announces the end in September 2019 to the [[Temporary Protected Status]] granted to nearly 200,000 Salvadorans by then-President [[George W. Bush]] following the [[January 2001 El Salvador earthquake|2001 El Salvador earthquakes]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/08/us/salvadorans-tps-end.html?hp&action=click&pgtype=Homepage&clickSource=story-heading&module=first-column-region&region=top-news&WT.nav=top-news |title=Trump Administration Says That Nearly 200,000 Salvadorans Must Leave |date=January 8, 2018 |publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> *President submits to the Senate 21 re-nominations for judicial posts, including two rated 'not qualified' by the [[American Bar Association|ABA]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/donald-trump-judicial-nominees-not-qualified_us_5a4fc2cae4b01e1a4b14e51d |title=Donald Trump Renominates Court Picks Rated 'Not Qualified' To Serve |date=January 8, 2018 |publisher=HuffPost}}</ref> *Vice President Pence describes ''Fire and Fury'' as a "book of fiction", while saying he has not read the book and does not intend to.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/mike-pence-dismisses-fire-and-fury-as-book-of-fiction/article/2645313 |title=Mike Pence dismisses 'Fire and Fury' as 'book of fiction' |date=January 8, 2018 |publisher=Washington Examiner}}</ref> |[[File:TrumpCollegeFootball'18.jpg|thumb|President Donald Trump on the field at [[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]] in Atlanta]] |- |Tuesday, '''January 9''' | *President Trump holds a bipartisan meeting with members of Congress discussing the topic of [[United States immigration debate|immigration]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/09/politics/donald-trump-immigration-contradictions/index.html |title=Trump contradicts self repeatedly in immigration meeting |date=January 10, 2018 |publisher=CNN}}</ref> *District judge [[William Alsup]] rules that the [[Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals|DACA program]] must remain in place while litigation continues over the Trump administration's September 5, 2017 decision to end it. On the following morning, Trump describes the US court system as "broken and unfair".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/10/judge-blocks-trump-dreamers-daca-program-immigrants |title=Federal court blocks Trump plan to end Daca program for immigrants |date=January 9, 2018 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> *Secretary Zinke announces that Florida will be exempted from oil drilling under the new policy announced on January 4.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/decision-to-exempt-florida-from-offshore-drilling-prompts-bipartisan-uproar/2018/01/10/1f5befa4-f625-11e7-beb6-c8d48830c54d_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-top-table-main_drillingpolitics-840pm%3Ahomepage%2Fstory |title=Decision to exempt Florida from offshore drilling prompts bipartisan uproar |date=January 10, 2018 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref> | |- |Wednesday, '''January 10''' | *President Trump describes Senator [[Dianne Feinstein]] as "sneaky" and a "disgrace" following her unilateral publication on January 9 of the Simpson testimony of August 2017 concerning research into potential crimes in respect of the 2016 election.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2018/01/11/world/politics-diplomacy-world/trump-says-seems-unlikely-hell-give-mueller-interview-democrat-hoax-russia-probe/#.Wlcjb2ciHF4 |title=Trump says it 'seems unlikely' he'll give Mueller interview over 'Democrat hoax' Russia probe |date=January 11, 2018 |publisher=Japan Times}}</ref> *President Trump reiterates that he will be reviewing [[libel]] law, describing the current law as "a sham and a disgrace".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/10/business/media/trump-libel-laws.html |title=Trump Renews Pledge to 'Take a Strong Look' at Libel Laws |date=January 10, 2018 |publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> *President Trump hosts Norway's Prime Minister [[Erna Solberg]] at the White House for talks and a joint press conference.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://qz.com/1177022/trump-reconsiders-the-paris-climate-agreement-and-praises-tesla-tsla-with-norways-erna-solberg/ |title=After 75 minutes with Norway's prime minister, Donald Trump goes green |work=[[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] |first=Heather |last=Timmons |date=January 10, 2018 |access-date=February 19, 2018}}</ref> |[[File:President Trump and Norway PM Erna Solberg.jpg|thumb|President Trump and Prime Minister Erne Solberg of Norway]]
|- |Thursday, '''January 11''' | *The Trump administration announces new state guidelines that [[Medicaid]] recipients may be required to work or volunteer, or enroll in education.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/trumps-new-guidelines-get-a-job-or-volunteer-if-you-want-medicaid/article/2645589 |title=Trump's new guidelines: Get a job or volunteer if you want Medicaid |date=January 11, 2018 |publisher=The Washington Examiner}}</ref> *''[[The Washington Post]]'' reports that President Trump, in a meeting with [[United States Senate|Sens.]] [[Lindsey Graham]] ([[Republican Party (United States)|R]]-[[List of United States Senators from South Carolina|SC]]) and [[Dick Durbin]] ([[Democratic Party (United States)|D]]-[[List of United States Senators from Illinois|IL]]) regarding immigration law reform, referred to [[Haiti]] and [[Africa]]n countries as "shithole countries" and expressed preference for immigrants from [[Norway]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-attacks-protections-for-immigrants-from-shithole-countries-in-oval-office-meeting/2018/01/11/bfc0725c-f711-11e7-91af-31ac729add94_story.html |title=Trump derides protections for immigrants from 'shithole' countries |last=Dawsey |first=Josh |date=January 11, 2018 |work=The Washington Post|access-date=January 12, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> On the following day, Trump denies using the term, but said that he used tough language in regards to the countries.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/trump-today-live-updates-us-president-haiti-uk-visit-africa-shithole-london-embassy-obama-racist-a8155036.html |title=Trump today - live updates: US President denies using word 's***hole' amid storm over cancelled UK visit |date=January 12, 2018 |publisher=The Independent}}</ref> Senator Durbin affirmed that Trump had made those remarks.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Timm |first1=Jane |title=Hillary Clinton: Trump's 'ignorant, racist views' |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/durbin-trump-said-shithole-repeatedly-comments-were-vile-racist-n837116 |publisher=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> *Vice President Pence visits [[Las Vegas]], Nevada, and speaks at nearby [[Nellis Air Force Base]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/Pastor-denounces-Trump-s-vulgar-comment-with-Mike-12499266.php |title=Pastor denounces Trump's vulgar comment with Mike Pence in attendance |date=January 15, 2018 |publisher=San Francisco Gate}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fox5vegas.com/story/37248881/mike-pence-offers-prayers-pep-talk-at-nevada-base |title=Mike Pence offers prayers, pep talk at Nevada base |date=January 12, 2018 |publisher=Fox 5 KVVU-TV}}</ref> | |- |Friday, '''January 12''' | *President Trump proclaims [[Martin Luther King Jr. Day]] for January 15.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/martin-luther-king-jr-s-son-trump-speech-rings-hollow-article-1.3754083 |title=Martin Luther King Jr.'s son says Trump doesn't understand why we honor his civil rights leader father |date=January 12, 2018 |publisher=New York Daily News}}</ref> *President Trump cancels a planned visit to the UK, blaming his predecessor, [[Barack Obama]], for a "bad deal" on the new embassy due to be opened in London, despite the fact it was agreed under [[George W. Bush]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-42657954 |title=Donald Trump cancels February visit to UK |accessdate=January 12, 2018 |publisher=BBC News |date=January 12, 2018}}</ref> *''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' reports that, in October 2016, President Trump's lawyer, [[Michael D. Cohen (lawyer)|Michael Cohen]], arranged a payment of $130,000 to the [[Pornographic film|adult-film]] actress [[Stormy Daniels]] in exchange for her silence regarding a 2006 extramarital affair.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-lawyer-arranged-130-000-payment-for-adult-film-stars-silence-1515787678 |title=Trump Lawyer Arranged $130,000 Payment for Adult-Film Star's Silence |last=Rothfeld |first=Michael |date=January 12, 2018 |work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=January 13, 2018 |last2=Palazzolo |first2=Joe |language=en-US |issn=0099-9660}}</ref> Cohen denies that Trump had sexual relations with Daniels.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/12/trump-affair-adult-film-star-stormy-daniels |title=Trump paid porn star $130,000 to stay silent over alleged affair – report |date=January 12, 2018 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> Fellow adult-film actress [[Alana Evans]] said Daniels told her she had "ended up with Donald in his hotel room."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Stern |first1=Marlow |last2=Snow |first2=Aurora |title=Porn Star: Donald Trump and Stormy Daniels Invited Me to Their Hotel Room |url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/porn-star-donald-trump-and-stormy-daniels-invited-me-to-their-hotel-room?ref=home |accessdate=January 13, 2018}}</ref> *Citing disagreements with the Trump administration, [[John D. Feeley|John Feeley]] announces his resignation as [[United States Ambassador to Panama|U.S. Ambassador to Panama]], effective March 9, 2018.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/12/politics/us-ambassador-panama-resigns-trump/index.html |title=US ambassador resigns, saying he can no longer work with Trump |last=CNN |first=Elise Labott, Zachary Cohen and Jim Sciutto, |work=CNN|access-date=January 13, 2018}}</ref> | |- |Saturday, '''January 13''' | *President Trump is briefed at the White House concerning Hawaii's emergency management protocol following a public disturbance due to [[2018 Hawaii false missile alert|a false alarm of an incoming ballistic missile]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/13/hawaii-ballistic-missile-threat-alert-false-alarm |title=Hawaii ballistic missile false alarm results in panic – and whisky drinking |date=January 14, 2018 |publisher=The Guardian}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 52 ==== |- | Monday, '''January 15''' | *Secretary of State [[Rex Tillerson]] co-hosts with Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister [[Chrystia Freeland]] the first of two days of talks in [[Vancouver]] concerning the North Korea crisis.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://vancouversun.com/news/local-news/u-s-secretary-of-state-rex-tillerson-in-vancouver-monday-to-co-host-north-korea-crisis-meeting |title=U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson in Vancouver Monday to co-host North Korea crisis meeting |date=January 15, 2017 |publisher=Vancouver Sun}}</ref> *Nine of the twelve members of the [[National Park Service|National Park System Advisory Board]] resign following Interior Secretary Zinke's refusal to convene meetings.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/nearly-all-members-of-national-park-service-advisory-panel-resign-in-frustration/2018/01/16/b322ef5e-fae3-11e7-ad8c-ecbb62019393_story.html |title=Nearly all members of National Park Service advisory panel resign in frustration |date=January 16, 2017 |work=The Washington Post}}</ref> *''The Wall Street Journal'' reports that Jared Kushner was warned in early 2017 by US intelligence officials that his friend [[Wendi Deng Murdoch]] may be a Chinese spy.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/kushner-warned-that-his-friend-wendi-deng-murdoch-may-be-a-chinese-spy-2018-1 |title=Jared Kushner reportedly was warned that his close friend Wendi Deng Murdoch may be a Chinese spy |date=January 16, 2018 |publisher=Business Insider}}</ref> | |- | Tuesday, '''January 16''' | *President Trump hosts Kazakhstan's President [[Nursultan Nazarbayev]] at the White House for talks and a joint press conference.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/16/kazakhstan-is-a-kleptocracy-ruled-by-an-autocrat-its-also-an-increasingly-important-strategic-ally.html |title=Kazakhstan is a 'kleptocracy' ruled by an autocrat. It's also an increasingly important strategic ally |date=January 16, 2017 |publisher=CNBC News}}</ref> *President Trump's former Chief Strategist [[Steve Bannon]] is questioned at a private sitting of the House Intelligence Committee. He is issued with a subpoena during the meeting upon citing [[executive privilege]] to refuse questions about the Trump transition and administration, but maintains his refusal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://uk.businessinsider.com/steve-bannon-interview-house-intelligence-committee-2018-1?r=US&IR=T |title=House panel subpoenas Bannon after he refuses to answer questions, citing executive privilege |date=January 16, 2017 |publisher=Business Insider}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/special-counsel-subpoenas-former-trump-aide-bannon-report-002800553.html |title=Former Trump aide Bannon refuses to comply with U.S. House subpoena |date=January 17, 2017 |publisher=Reuters/Yahoo}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''January 17''' | *In an Oval Office interview for [[Reuters]], President Trump accuses Russia of harming Chinese/American efforts to solve the ongoing [[2017–18 North Korea crisis|North Korean nuclear crisis]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump accuses Russia of helping North Korea evade sanctions; says U.S. needs more missile defense |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-exclusive/exclusive-trump-accuses-russia-of-helping-north-korea-evade-sanctions-says-u-s-needs-more-missile-defense-idUSKBN1F62KO |publisher=Reuters |date=January 17, 2018}}</ref> *''[[In Touch Weekly]]'' publishes excerpts from a 2011 interview with adult-film actress Stormy Daniels alleging a 2006 extramarital affair with Trump. The magazine describes Daniels passing a [[polygraph]] and her friend and ex-husband both corroborating the interview.<ref>{{cite web |title='In Touch' Explosive Interview With Stormy Daniels: Donald Trump Cheated on Melania With Me |url=http://www.intouchweekly.com/posts/stormy-daniels-affair-donald-trump-151571 |publisher=[[In Touch Weekly]] |accessdate=January 18, 2018}}</ref> *President Trump announces the winners of the "[[Fake News Awards]]," despite criticism from Republican senators [[Jeff Flake]] and [[John McCain]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.thenews.com.pk/latest/269991-trump-unveils-fake-news-awards |title=Trump unveils 'Fake News Awards' |work=The News International |agency=AFP |date=January 18, 2018 |accessdate=January 21, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Thursday, '''January 18''' | *President Trump delivers a speech at a factory near [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]. He offers his support for Republican candidate [[Rick Saccone]] in the [[Pennsylvania's 18th congressional district special election, 2018|upcoming March 13 special election for Pennsylvania's 18th district]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump wades into PA race seen as test of GOP strength |url=http://www.latimes.com/sns-bc-us--house-pennsylvania-trump-20180118-story.html |publisher=The Los Angeles Times |date=January 19, 2018}}</ref> *The [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]] passes a short-term government budget in advance of a deadline of midnight January 19–20.<ref name="foxnews1">{{cite web |title=Trump says Democrats 'are needed' to avert government shutdown with just hours until deadline |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/19/trump-says-democrats-are-needed-to-avert-government-shutdown-with-just-hours-until-deadline.html |publisher=Fox News |date=January 19, 2018}}</ref> *It is widely reported that Hungarian police have an active arrest warrant, issued on September 17, 2016, against former Trump White House advisor [[Sebastian Gorka]]. The warrant concerns alleged abuse of firearms.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ex-Trump aide Sebastian Gorka was subject of Hungarian arrest warrant while at White House |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-sebastian-gorka-hungary-arrest-warrant-20180118-story.html |publisher=The Chicago Tribune |date=January 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Hungarian Police Have A Warrant Out For Former Trump Adviser Sebastian Gorka |url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/hayesbrown/hungarian-warrant-for-sebastian-gorka |publisher=BuzzFeed News |date=January 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Sebastian Gorka was White House aide while a fugitive from Hungarian justice |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/jan/18/sebastian-gorka-hungary-fugitive-white-house-aide |publisher=The Guardian |date=January 18, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Szijjártó úgy találkozott Gorka Sebestyénnel Washingtonban, hogy a férfit itthon elfogatóparancs alapján körözik |url=https://444.hu/2018/01/18/szijjarto-ugy-talalkozott-gorka-sebestyennel-washingtonban-hogy-a-ferfit-itthon-elfogatoparancs-alapjan-korozik |publisher=444 |date=January 18, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''January 19''' | *President Trump states on Twitter that Democratic votes will be needed in the Senate to prevent a [[United States federal government shutdown of 2018|government shutdown]] at midnight. He writes, "but they want illegal immigration and weak borders".<ref name="foxnews1"/> *German periodical ''[[Manager Magazin]]'' reports that [[Deutsche Bank]] has presented to Germany's financial authority, [[Federal Financial Supervisory Authority|BaFin]], evidence concerning "suspicious money transfers" by White House advisor Jared Kushner. ''MM'' reports that this information is due to be handed to Robert Mueller's inquiry.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/politics/deutsche-bank-investigating-jared-kushner-his-companies-for-suspicious-money-transfers/ar-AAuT87P |title=Deutsche Bank Investigating Jared Kushner, His Companies For Suspicious Money Transfers |publisher=International Business Times/Yahoo |date=January 19, 2018}}</ref> Deutsche Bank on January 22 denies the report, and announces that it is taking legal action.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-deutsche-bank-report/deutsche-bank-denies-manager-magazin-report-on-kushner-idUSKBN1FB1SG |title=Deutsche Bank denies Manager Magazin report on Kushner |date=January 23, 2018 |publisher=Reuters}}</ref> | |- | Saturday, '''January 20''' | *A [[United States federal government shutdown of 2018|federal government shutdown]] begins, after the Senate fails to pass a continuing resolution to maintain funding for the government.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/19/us/politics/senate-showdown-government-shutdown-trump.html |title=Government Shutdown Begins as Budget Talks Falter in Senate |last=Stolberg |first=Sheryl Gay |date=2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=January 20, 2018 |last2=Kaplan |first2=Thomas |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref> *Vice President Pence arrives in [[Cairo, Egypt]] at the start of a tour of Africa and the Middle East.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://uk.news.yahoo.com/pence-heads-mideast-amid-israel-embassy-storm-003501540.html |title=Pence heads to Mideast amid Israel embassy storm |date=January 20, 2018 |publisher=Yahoo News}}</ref> *The second year of the Trump presidency begins. |[[File:President Donald Trump is seen "working" in this photo released by the White House on Jan. 20, 2018.png|thumb|President Donald Trump on the phone in the Oval Office.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/01/white-house-releases-hilarious-photos-to-show-trump-is-working-during-shutdown.html |title=White House Releases Hilarious Photos to Show Trump Is "Working" During Shutdown |last=Politi |first=Daniel |work=Slate Magazine|access-date=January 27, 2018 |language=en}}</ref>]]
|- | Sunday, '''January 21''' | *Vice President Pence meets with [[King Abdullah II]] of Jordan in [[Amman]]. Abdullah criticizes the US' decision to recognize Jerusalem as the Israeli capital. Pence reaffirms the US' respect towards Jordan's role as the guardian of Jerusalem's Islamic holy sites.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/21/world/middleeast/pence-jordan-king-abdullah.html |title=Pence and Jordan's King 'Agree to Disagree' on Jerusalem |date=January 21, 2018 |publisher=The New York Times}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 53 ==== |- | Monday, '''January 22''' | *During the third day of the federal government shutdown, President Trump accuses the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] of precipitating the shutdown "in the interests of their far left base".<ref>{{cite news |last1=Costa |first1=Robert |last2=Werner |first2=Erica |last3=O'Keefe |first3=Ed |last4=Viebeck |first4=Elise |title=House votes to end government shutdown, sending legislation to Trump |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/trump-slams-democrats-as-third-day-of-government-shutdown-begins/2018/01/22/3a3eecf0-ff25-11e7-9d31-d72cf78dbeee_story.html?hpid=hp_hp-banner-main_shutdownmon-0921am%3Ahomepage%2Fstory |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=January 22, 2018 |accessdate=January 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Cullen |first1=Terri |last2=Calia |first2=Mike |title=Trump again attacks Democrats over shutdown hours before expected Senate vote |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/22/government-shutdown-trump-blames-democrats.html |publisher=CNBC |date=January 22, 2018 |accessdate=January 23, 2018}}</ref> *President Trump signs a [https://www.senate.gov/legislative/LIS/roll_call_lists/roll_call_vote_cfm.cfm?congress=115&session=2&vote=00017 bi-partisan bill], which passed Congress with support from legislators of both parties, officially ending the [[United States federal government shutdown of 2018|government shutdown that began three days earlier]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Min Kim |first1=Seung |last2=Everett |first2=Burgess |last3=Schor |first3=Elana |title=Congress votes to end shutdown |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/22/government-shutdown-2018-senate-vote-354966 |work=Politico |date=January 22, 2018 |accessdate=January 23, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=Bruce |first1=Mary |last2=Khan |first2=Mariam |last3=Kelsey |first3=Adam |last4=Turner |first4=Trish |title=Trump signs funding bill to end shutdown, immigration debate continues |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/congress-agrees-fund-government-weeks-immigration-debate-continues/story?id=52522136 |publisher=ABC News |date=January 22, 2018 |accessdate=January 23, 2018}}</ref> The bill provides funds until February 8, 2018.<ref>{{cite news |title=House votes to end government shutdown, sending legislation to Trump |url=https://www.sltrib.com/news/nation-world/2018/01/22/senate-votes-to-end-shutdown-sending-house-a-short-term-spending-bill-to-fund-government-through-feb-8/ |publisher=Salt Lake Tribune |date=January 22, 2018}}</ref> *Vice President Pence delivers a speech at Israel's [[Knesset]], announcing that the U.S. will relocate its embassy from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem by the end of 2019. A number of Arab members of Parliament are ejected while protesting.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mike Pence in Israel: Arab politicians forced out of Knesset for protesting during US Vice President's speech |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/mike-pence-israel-knesset-speech-protest-jerusalem-us-embassy-palestine-palestinian-a8173271.html |publisher=The Independent |date=January 22, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Pence Tells Israeli Lawmakers: U.S. Embassy in Jerusalem Will Open Before End of 2019 |url=https://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/pence-tells-israeli-lawmakers-u-s-embassy-in-jerusalem-will-open-before-end-of-2019-1.5750679 |publisher=Haaretz |date=January 22, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Tuesday, '''January 23''' | *Vice President Pence visits Jerusalem's [[Western Wall]].<ref>{{cite news |title=The Damning Silence at the Heart of Mike Pence's Speech in Jerusalem |url=https://www.haaretz.com/opinion/.premium-damning-silence-at-the-heart-of-pence-s-jerusalem-speech-1.5763874 |publisher=Haaretz |date=January 22, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''January 24''' | *President Trump announces during remarks at the White House that he is willing to testify to Mueller under oath, stating, "I would love to do it, and I would like to do it as soon as possible".<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump says he would speak to Mueller under oath in Russia investigation |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-says-he-would-speak-to-mueller-under-oath-in-russia-investigation/2018/01/24/edb33750-015a-11e8-8acf-ad2991367d9d_story.html |work=The Washington Post |date=January 24, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Thursday, '''January 25''' | *President Trump arrives in [[Davos]], [[Switzerland]] to attend the 2018 Davos [[World Economic Forum]]. He is the first U.S. President to personally attend the annual Davos conference since President [[Bill Clinton]] in 2000. [[United States Secretary of the Treasury|U.S. Treasury Secretary]] [[Steve Mnuchin]] is head of the U.S. delegation, which is the largest ever to attend the forum. *''[[The New York Times]]'' first reports that President Trump ordered the dismissal of the special counsel, [[Robert Mueller]], in June 2017, on three alleged pretexts of conflicts of interest, but retreated upon the threatened resignation of White House counsel [[Don McGahn]]; this elevated concerns of possible obstruction of justice. The report is confirmed by ''[[The Washington Post]]''.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump Ordered Mueller Fired, but Backed Off When White House Counsel Threatened to Quit |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/25/us/politics/trump-mueller-special-counsel-russia.html |publisher=The New York Times |date=January 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trump-moved-to-fire-mueller-in-june-bringing-white-house-counsel-to-the-brink-of-leaving/2018/01/25/9184a49e-0238-11e8-bb03-722769454f82_story.html |title=Trump moved to fire Mueller in June, bringing White House counsel to the brink of leaving |last=Helderman |first=Rosalind S. |date=January 25, 2018 |work=The Washington Post|access-date=January 26, 2018 |last2=Dawsey |first2=Josh |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> *First Lady [[Melania Trump]] visits the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] in Washington D.C.<ref>{{cite news |title=Melania Trump 'shuns the White House to spend the night at D.C. hotels' |url=http://metro.co.uk/2018/01/26/melania-trump-shuns-white-house-spend-night-d-c-hotels-7264575/ |publisher=Metro |date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''January 26''' | *President Trump denies ordering the dismissal of Mueller, describing it as 'fake news'.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump-Russia inquiry: President denies trying to fire Robert Mueller |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-42827507 |publisher=BBC |date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> *President Trump returns to the White House from Switzerland.<ref>{{cite news |title=The Latest: Trump back at White House after Davos trip |url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/E/EU_TRUMP_THE_LATEST |work=Associated Press |date=January 26, 2018}}</ref> |[[File:Trump- I'm Here to Deliver a Simple Message.webm|thumb|Trump at WEF: "I'm Here to Deliver a Simple Message"]]
|- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 54 ==== |- | Monday, '''January 29''' | *The Trump administration submits five reports to Congress as mandated by the [[Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act]] (CAATSA), including two versions (both classified and unclassified) of the report ″regarding senior political figures and oligarchs in the Russian Federation and Russian parastatal entities″.<ref>{{cite news |title=Treasury Releases CAATSA Reports, Including on Senior Foreign Political Figures and Oligarchs in the Russian Federation |url=https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sm0271 |publisher=US Department of the Treasury |date=January 29, 2018}}</ref> The unclassified list published the following day by the Treasury Department contains names of 210 people, including 96 [[Russian oligarch|Russian tycoons]] close to president Vladimir Putin with wealth of $1 billion or more, as well as top Russian statespersons and officials, excluding Vladimir Putin, all information having been drawn from public sources.<ref>{{cite news |title=U.S. names Kremlin outliers in 'telephone directory' sanctions report |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-russia-sanctions-criticism/u-s-names-kremlin-outliers-in-telephone-directory-sanctions-report-idUSKBN1FJ2DW |agency=Reuters |date=January 30, 2018}}</ref> *Former pharmaceutical executive and former [[United States Deputy Secretary of Health and Human Services|U.S. Deputy Secretary of HHS]], [[Alex Azar]], is sworn in as the 24th [[United States Secretary of Health and Human Services]], after being confirmed by the [[United States Senate|U.S. Senate]] by a 55–43 vote on January 24. Azar replaces [[Tom Price (American politician)|Tom Price]] who resigned on September 29, 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/24/us/politics/alex-azar-health-and-human-services-secretary-confirmed-senate.html |title=Senate Confirms Trump Nominee Alex Azar as Health Secretary |last=Pear |first=Robert |date=2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=January 29, 2018 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-alex-azar-secretary-health-human-services-20180129-story.html |title=Alex Azar sworn in as secretary of Health and Human Services |last=Thomas |first=Ken |work=chicagotribune.com|access-date=January 29, 2018 |language=en-US}}</ref> *[[Deputy Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation|Deputy FBI Director]] [[Andrew McCabe]] resigns from his position, but remained as part of the FIB, after criticism from President Trump in preceding weeks. McCabe had been expected to step down in March.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/29/us/politics/andrew-mccabe-fbi.html |title=Andrew McCabe Steps Down as F.B.I. Deputy Director Under Pressure |last=Goldman |first=Adam |date=2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=January 29, 2018 |last2=Apuzzo |first2=Matt |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/fbis-andrew-mccabe-leaving-deputy-director-job-will-retire-in-march/2018/01/29/35b1bbd4-051c-11e8-b48c-b07fea957bd5_story.html |title=FBI's Andrew McCabe leaving deputy director job, will retire in March |last=Barrett |first=Devlin |date=January 29, 2018 |work=The Washington Post|access-date=January 29, 2018 |last2=Zapotosky |first2=Matt |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref> | |- | Tuesday, '''January 30''' | *President Trump delivers his first official [[2018 State of the Union Address|State of the Union Address]] with a wide-ranging speech covering matters of natural disasters, terrorism, immigration, economic growth, patriotism and the [[Nuclear weapons of the United States|US nuclear arsenal]]. He calls on Congress for a $1.5tn infrastructure investment bill, and calls for an end to political division.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump calls for unity, then touts GOP agenda in State of the Union speech |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/politics/ct-trump-state-of-the-union-20180130-story.html |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date=January 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump calls to 'set aside our differences' in State of the Union address |url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2018/01/30/trump-calls-to-set-aside-our-differences-in-state-union-address.html |publisher=Fox News |date=January 30, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Trump's State of the Union 2018 - live updates: President declares 'era of economic surrender totally over' in address |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/us-politics/donald-trump-state-of-the-union-live-updates-2018-latest-stream-transcript-congress-joe-kennedy-a8185046.html |publisher=The Independent |date=January 31, 2018}}</ref> *The White House confirms that President Trump has signed an order keeping open the [[Guantanamo Bay detention camp]] in Cuba.<ref>{{cite news |title=Trump signs executive order to keep Guantanamo Bay prison open |url=https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/trump-signs-executive-order-keep-021700585.html |publisher=Yahoo News |date=January 31, 2018}}</ref> *Treasury Secretary [[Steve Mnuchin]] announces that US sanctions against Russian oligarchs will follow the previous day's list, and denies that the administration is "slow-walking" the process.<ref>{{cite news |title=Mnuchin says Russia sanctions are coming after 'oligarchs' list |url=http://www.smh.com.au/world/mnuchin-says-russia-sanctions-are-coming-after-oligarchs-list-20180130-h0qwob.html |publisher=Sydney Morning Herald |date=January 31, 2018}}</ref> | [[File:President Trump Delivers the State of the Union Address.webm|thumb|Video of the 2018 State of the Union Address]] |- | Wednesday, '''January 31''' | *Doctor [[Brenda Fitzgerald]] resigns as Director of the [[Center for Disease Control]] over conflicts of interest.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Hellmann |first1=Jessie |title=CDC head resigns after report she traded tobacco stocks |url=http://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/371592-cdc-head-resigns-after-report-she-traded-tobacco-stocks |website=thehill.com |publisher=The Hill |accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref> | |}
=== February 2018 ===
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Events ! Photos |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 54 ==== |- | Thursday, '''February 1''' | *[[Thomas A. Shannon Jr.|Tom Shannon]], the United States [[Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs]], announces he will be resigning for personal reasons. The [[United States Department of State|State Department]]'s third-ranking official and its most senior career diplomat says he will stay on until a successor is named.<ref>{{cite web |last=Wroughton |first=Lesley |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-diplomact-shannon/no-3-u-s-diplomat-shannon-stepping-down-ap-idUSKBN1FL5HO |title=No. 3 U.S. diplomat quits in latest departure under Trump |publisher=Reuters |date=February 2, 2018 |accessdate=February 7, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''February 2''' | *President Trump declassifies the [[Nunes memo]] and authorizes Congress to release it.<ref>{{cite news |last=Watson |first=Kathryn |url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/nunes-memo-declassified-today-gop-despite-fbi-warnings-grave-concern-live-updates/ |title=GOP memo released, after Trump declassifies it |publisher=CBS News |accessdate=February 7, 2018}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 55 ==== |- | Monday, '''February 5''' | *At a speech in Cincinnati, Ohio President Trump claims that Congressional Democrats, who "were like death and un-American" in not applauding during his State of the Union speech, were "treasonous" and that "we call that [[treason]]".<ref>{{cite web |title=He Dares Call It Treason |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/politics/archive/2018/02/one-dares-call-it-treason/552395/ |work=[[The Atlantic]] |date=February 6, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Cillizza |first1=Chris |title=Donald Trump thinks not clapping for him is 'treasonous' |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/02/05/politics/trump-speech-treason/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=February 7, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Tuesday, '''February 6''' | *While Congress was preparing a continuing resolution for a temporary budget, President Trump declared, "I'd love to see a shutdown" if American immigration laws were not tightened. He also said "it's worth it for our country".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Merica |first1=Dan |last2=Mattingly |first2=Phil |title=Trump: 'I'd love to see a shutdown' over immigration |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/02/06/politics/government-shutdown-immigration-donald-trump/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=February 8, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''February 7''' | *[[White House Office|White House]] [[White House Office of the Staff Secretary|Staff Secretary]] Rob Porter resigns from his position following two public allegations of spousal abuse.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Swan |first1=Jonathan |title=White House staff secretary Rob Porter resigns amid abuse allegations |url=https://www.axios.com/white-house-staff-secetary-rob-porter-resigns-abuse-allegations-9bf97afb-a59f-409f-ba74-8fb7aee20b65.html |website=www.axios.com |publisher=Axios |accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref> *Associate Attorney General [[Rachel Brand]] resigns in order to enter the private sector.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Kutner |first1=Max |title=Justice Dept official is stepping down |url=http://www.newsweek.com/rachel-brand-associate-attorney-general-steps-down-802536 |website=www.newsweek.com |publisher=Newsweek |accessdate=March 7, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''February 9''' | *[[United States federal government shutdown of 2018#February funding gap|Federal funding lapsed for the second time in 2018]] after Republican Senator [[Rand Paul]] delayed the vote on a temporary appropriations bill by objecting to measures requiring [[unanimous consent]] to expedite the parliamentary process.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/powerpost/house-leaders-scramble-to-win-support-for-budget-deal-ahead-of-midnight-deadline/2018/02/08/4812e996-0cd9-11e8-8b0d-891602206fb7_story.html |title=Government shuts down as budget bill stalls in Congress |last=Werner |first=Erica |date=February 9, 2018 |work=The Washington Post|access-date=February 9, 2018 |last2=DeBonis |first2=Mike |language=en-US |issn=0190-8286}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/02/08/government-shutdown-dumbest-ever-400988 |title=The dumbest shutdown ever |last=Bade |first=Rachel |date=February 8, 2018 |work=Politico|access-date=February 9, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url= |last2=Kim |first2=Seung Min}}</ref> *Congress passes a budget bill to end the federal funding gap within six hours; President Trump signs the bill into law.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Bresnahan |first1=John |last2=Scholtes |first2=Jennifer |last3=Caygle |first3=Heather |title=Shutdown ends after Trump signs budget deal |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/02/08/congress-massive-budget-deal-2018-398189 |publisher=[[Politico]] |accessdate=February 15, 2018}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 56 ==== |- | Monday, '''February 12''' | *President Trump sends his $4.4 trillion 2019 [[United States federal budget|budget]] proposal to [[United States Congress|Congress]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Davis |first=Julie Hirschfeld |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/12/us/politics/white-house-budget-congress.html |title=White House Proposes $4.4 Trillion Budget That Adds $7 Trillion to Deficits |date=February 12, 2018 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref> *President Trump introduces his $1.5 trillion federal infrastructure plan to several governors and mayors at the [[White House]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Shelbourne |first=Mallory |url=http://thehill.com/policy/transportation/infrastructure/373408-white-house-releases-55-page-infrastructure-proposal |title=White House releases 55-page, $1.5 trillion infrastructure plan |date=February 12, 2018 |work=The Hill |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Tuesday, '''February 13''' | *President Trump's personal lawyer Michael Cohen acknowledged that in 2016, he paid $130,000 of his own money to adult-film actress Stormy Daniels. Cohen further said that [[The Trump Organization]] and the [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2016|Trump campaign]] were not involved in the payment and did not reimburse him.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tatum |first1=Sophie |last2=Cuomo |first2=Chris |title=Trump's lawyer says he paid $130,000 to porn star ahead of election |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/02/13/politics/michael-cohen-stormy-daniels-payment/index.html |accessdate=February 15, 2018}}</ref> It was earlier reported that the payment was [[hush money]] for Daniels' silence regarding an alleged extramarital affair with Trump in 2006.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Tatum |first1=Sophie |title=WSJ: Cohen paid porn star through private LLC created just weeks before election |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/01/18/politics/michael-cohen-stormy-daniels-essential-consultants-llc/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=February 15, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''February 16''' | *''[[The New Yorker]]'' reports that Trump had a nine-month extramarital affair with ''[[Playboy]]'' model [[Karen McDougal]] from June 2006, citing handwritten memoirs by McDougal provided by her friend. ''The New Yorker'' also corroborated a 2016 ''Wall Street Journal'' report that [[American Media, Inc]] (AMI) had paid $150,000 for exclusive rights to McDougal's story, but never published it. AMI has described the story as not credible, and a spokesperson for the White House denied the affair.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Farrow |first1=Ronan |title=Donald Trump, a Playboy Model, and a System for Concealing Infidelity |url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/donald-trump-a-playboy-model-and-a-system-for-concealing-infidelity-national-enquirer-karen-mcdougal |work=[[The New Yorker]] |accessdate=February 17, 2018}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 57 ==== |- | Tuesday, '''February 20''' | * President Trump orders the [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] to prepare regulations to ban devices that allow [[semi-automatic firearm|semi-automatic rifles]] to become fully automatic, such as the [[bump stocks]] used in the [[2017 Las Vegas shooting]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Carter |first1=Brandon |last2=Wheeler |first2=Lydia |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/374722-trump-to-take-steps-to-ban-bump-stocks |title=Trump to take steps to ban bump stocks |date=February 20, 2018 |work=The Hill |accessdate=March 1, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Saturday, '''February 24''' | *A [[Democratic Memo|Democratic memo]] titled ''Correcting the Record -- The Russia Investigation'' in response to the Nunes memo, is released after redacting by the FBI.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-24/public-release-of-democratic-rebuttal-memo-could-be-imminent |title=Democrats' Memo Released Countering GOP Account of Russia Probe |last=House |first=Billy |date=February 24, 2018 |work=Bloomberg News |accessdate=February 25, 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Prokop |first=Andrew |title=Democrats' response to the Nunes memo was just released |website=Vox |date=February 24, 2018 |url=https://www.vox.com/2018/2/24/17048764/schiff-memo-nunes-read | access-date=February 24, 2018 |quote=Here's the full text of the Schiff memo .. Democrats on the committee led by Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA) accused the memo of being misleading, and put together their own memo in response.}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 58 ==== |- | Tuesday, '''February 27''' | * Josh Raffel, a senior communications aide, announced his resignation from the administration.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rucker |first1=Philip |last2=Parker |first2=Ashley |title=Josh Raffel, senior communications aide, is leaving the White House |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-politics/wp/2018/02/27/josh-raffel-senior-communications-aide-is-leaving-the-white-house/ |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=March 1, 2018}}</ref> *[[Joseph Yun]], the top diplomat in charge of America's Korean policy, announces his resignation.<ref>{{cite news |title=Envoy's resignation leaves void at head of Trump's Korea diplomacy |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/feb/27/joseph-yun-us-north-korea-diplomat |work=The Guardian |accessdate=March 7, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''February 28''' | * At the [[lying in honor]] of evangelical preacher [[Billy Graham]] in the [[U.S. Capitol rotunda]], President Trump and congressional leaders praise Graham.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Rossman |first1=Sean |last2=Icsman |first2=Marilyn |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation-now/2018/02/28/trump-congress-lay-wreaths-preacher-billy-graham-lies-honor-capitol/379092002/ |title=President Trump, Congress honor preacher Billy Graham at Capitol |work=USA Today |date=February 28, 2018 |accessdate=March 5, 2018}}</ref> * A day after being interviewed by the [[United States House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence|U.S. House Intelligence Committee]], White House Communications Director [[Hope Hicks]] submits her resignation.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Haberman |first=Maggie |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/28/us/politics/hope-hicks-resign-communications-director.html |title=Hope Hicks to Resign as White House Communications Director |date=February 28, 2018 |work=The New York Times|access-date=February 28, 2018|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url= |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331|author-link=Maggie Haberman}}</ref> |[[File:Billy Graham's memorial service.jpg|thumb|Trump and Melania at [[Billy Graham]]'s lying in honor]] |}
=== March 2018 === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Events ! Photos |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 58 ==== |- | Thursday, '''March 1''' | *Two-time [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] champions [[Golden State Warriors]] toured the [[National Museum of African American History and Culture]] as an alternative to the traditional White House visit.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cancain |first1=Dan |title=Golden State Warriors praise 'unifying' visit to black history museaum after snubbing Donald Trump |url=http://www.newsweek.com/warriors-praise-unifying-visit-african-american-museum-after-snubbing-donald-825316 |website=www.newsweek.com |publisher=Newsweek |accessdate=March 7, 2018}}</ref> *The [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]] removes the blanket ban on imports of [[Trophy hunting|sport-hunted trophies]] of elephants from certain African countries originally imposed by the Obama administration. The trophies will now be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. The organization also withdrew several [[Endangered Species Act]] findings regarding [[African elephants]], [[lion]]s and the [[bontebok]] antelopes.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Wallace |first1=Gregory |title=Trump admin to allow elephant trophy imports on 'case-by-case' basis |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/03/06/politics/elephant-trophies-trump/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref> *[[Roberta S. Jacobson|Roberta Jacobson]], the Ambassador to Mexico, resigns from her post.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ahmed |first1=Azam |title=U.S. Ambassador to Mexico to Quit Amid Tense Relations Under Trump |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/01/world/americas/us-ambassador-mexico.html |website=www.nytimes.com |publisher=New York Times |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref>
| |- |Saturday, '''March 3''' | * In a private speech to Republican donors at [[Mar-a-Lago]], Trump says that "it's great" that China's [[Xi Jinping]] was able to become "president for life", and that "maybe we'll have to give that a shot some day."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Liptak |first1=Kevin |title=Trump on China's Xi consolidating power: 'Maybe we'll give that a shot some day' |url=https://edition.cnn.com/2018/03/03/politics/trump-maralago-remarks/index.html |publisher=CNN |accessdate=March 4, 2018}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 59 ==== |- | Tuesday, '''March 6''' | * The [[U.S. Office of Special Counsel]] (OSC) says that [[Counselor to the President]] [[Kellyanne Conway]] violated federal law in the form of the [[Hatch Act of 1939|Hatch Act]] during two television interviews in 2017 by advocating for the defeat of [[Doug Jones (politician)|Doug Jones]] and the election of [[Roy Moore]] for [[United States Senate special election in Alabama, 2017|Alabama's election for a Senate seat]]. The White House has disputed this finding by the OSC.<ref>{{cite news |last=Mallin |first=Alexander |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/kellyanne-conway-found-violated-hatch-act/story?id=53557326 |title=Kellyanne Conway found to have violated law banning use of office for political ends |date=March 6, 2018 |work=ABC News |accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref> *Chief economic adviser [[Gary Cohn (investment banker)|Gary Cohn]] announces plan to resign after President Trump announced he would impose tariffs on steel and aluminum imports.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mangan |first1=Dan |last2=Pramuk |first2=Jacob |title=Gary Cohn resigns as Trump's top economic advisor |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/06/gary-cohn-plans-to-resign-as-trumps-top-economic-advisor-new-york-times.html |website=www.cnbc.com |publisher=CNBC |accessdate=March 6, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''March 7''' | * [[White House Press Secretary]] [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] says that President Trump's personal attorneys have won an arbitration case against adult-film actress Stormy Daniels.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trump won Stormy Daniels legal case in arbitration: White House |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-trump-daniels/trump-won-stormy-daniels-legal-case-in-arbitration-white-house-idUSKCN1GJ3BT |publisher=Reuters |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref> [[NBC News]] reports that Trump's lawyer, Michael Cohen, on February 27 initiated a private arbitration case against Daniels and obtained a restraining order that states that Daniels will face penalties if she discusses, in public, her alleged relationship with Trump. Daniels has filed a lawsuit that her non-disclosure agreement regarding her alleged relationship with Trump is invalid because Trump never signed it.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Fitzpatrick |first1=Sarah |title=Trump lawyer Michael Cohen tries to silence adult-film star Stormy Daniels |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/trump-lawyer-michael-cohen-tries-silence-stormy-daniels-n854646 |publisher=[[NBC News]] |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref> * U.S. Forest Service Chief Tom Tooke resigns from his post.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Zhao |first1=Christina |title=Forest Service chief resigns amidst sexual misconduct investigation |url=http://www.newsweek.com/who-tony-tooke-forest-service-chief-resigns-amid-sexual-misconduct-836081 |website=www.newsweek.com |publisher=Newsweek |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Thursday, '''March 8''' | * President Trump signs proclamations which will impose [[tariff]]s on imported steel and aluminum from most countries in 15 days. [[Canada]] and [[Mexico]] are initially exempted from these tariffs while they talk with the U.S. about renegotiating [[NAFTA]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Restuccia |first1=Andrew |last2=Palmer |first2=Doug |url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/03/08/trumps-tariff-details-debated-765614 |title=Trump imposes steel, aluminum tariffs with few exceptions |work=Politico |date=March 8, 2018 |accessdate=March 8, 2018}}</ref> * President Trump accepts an invitation to [[Trump–Kim meeting|meet]] with [[North Korea]]n Leader [[Kim Jong-un]] by May 2018.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/south-koreans-deliver-letter-trump-kim-jong-un-n855051 |title=President Trump agrees to meet with North Korea's Kim Jong Un by May |work=NBC News|access-date=March 9, 2018 |language=en}}</ref> * President Trump meets with video-game executives to discuss how violent video games might contribute to mass shootings.<ref>{{cite news |last=Romm |first=Tony |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2018/03/08/inside-trumps-private-meeting-with-the-video-game-industry-and-its-critics/ |title=Inside Trump's private meeting with the video-game industry — and its critics |date=March 8, 2018 |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=March 9, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''March 9''' | * President Trump pardons [[Kristian Saucier]], who was convicted of unauthorized possession and retention of national defense information.<ref>{{cite web |last=Olson |first=Wyatt |url=https://www.stripes.com/news/us/trump-pardons-sailor-convicted-of-photographing-sub-s-nuclear-propulsion-system-1.515957 |title=Trump pardons sailor convicted of photographing sub's nuclear propulsion system |work=Stars and Stripes |date=March 9, 2018 |accessdate=March 10, 2018}}</ref> * White House Press Secretary [[Sarah Huckabee Sanders]] says that the White House would need to see "concrete and verifiable steps" toward the denuclearization of North Korea before Trump would meet with Kim Jong-un. An unidentified Trump official tells ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' that Trump has still accepted Jong-un's invitation.<ref>{{cite news |last=Jacobs |first=Peter |url=http://www.businessinsider.sg/trump-kim-jong-un-north-korea-meeting-white-house-backtracking-2018-3/ |title=The White House already looks as if it's backtracking on Trump's meeting with Kim Jong Un |date=March 9, 2018 |work=Business Insider |accessdate=March 10, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Saturday, '''March 10''' | * President Trump holds a rally at the [[Pittsburgh International Airport]] to support [[Rick Saccone]] in an upcoming [[Pennsylvania's 18th congressional district special election, 2018|special election]]. He introduces his [[Donald Trump presidential campaign, 2020|2020 campaign]] slogan: "Keep America Great!"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cochrane |first1=Emily |last2=Haberman |first2=Maggie |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/10/us/politics/trump-rally-pittsburgh.html |title=Trump Hosts Fiery Rally on the Heels of a Whirlwind Week |date=March 10, 2018 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=March 12, 2018}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 60 ==== |- | Sunday, '''March 11''' | * The Trump administration proposes gun and school safety measures, including improving the system of background checks and training school personnel to handle firearms.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Malloy |first1=Allie |last2=Gray |first2=Noah |last3=Bohn |first3=Kevin |url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/11/politics/white-house-gun-school-safety-proposals/index.html |title=White House unveils gun and school safety proposals |publisher=CNN |date=March 11, 2018 |accessdate=March 12, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Monday, '''March 12''' | * Citing national security concerns, President Trump blocks [[Broadcom Limited|Broadcom]]'s proposed acquisition of [[Qualcomm]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Aiello|first=Chloe |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/03/12/trump-issues-order-prohibiting-broadcoms-bid-to-take-over-qualcomm.html|title=Trump blocks Broadcom-Qualcomm deal, citing national security concerns|date=March 12, 2018|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Tuesday, '''March 13''' | * President Trump fires [[Rex Tillerson]] as [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], names former CIA director [[Mike Pompeo]] as the new Secretary of State, and names [[Gina Haspel]] as the new director of the CIA.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-43388723|title=Trump fires Tillerson as secretary of state|date=2018-03-13|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-GB}}</ref> * [[Steve Goldstein (diplomat)|Steve Goldstein]], the United States Under Secretary of State for Public Diplomacy and Public Affairs and fourth ranking diplomatic official, is fired by the White House. Trump designates [[Heather Nauert]] as Goldstein's replacement.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Labott|first1=Elise|title=Senior Tillerson aide Steve Goldstein fired|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/13/politics/goldstein-tillerson-fired/index.html|website=www.cnn.com|publisher=CNN|accessdate=March 14, 2018}}</ref> * [[John McEntee (political aide)|John McEntee]], a long-time personal assistant to President Trump, is fired and escorted from the White House. McEntee then joins Trump's re-election campaign as a senior adviser, along with [[Katrina Pierson]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Collins|first1=Kaitlan|last2=Diamond|first2=Jeremy|last3=Deleny|first3=Jeff|title=Longtime Trump aide fired over financial crime investigation|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/13/politics/john-mcentee-white-house-security-clearance/index.html|website=www.cnn.com|publisher=CNN|accessdate=March 14, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''March 14''' | * President Trump chooses [[Larry Kudlow]] as director of the [[National Economic Council (United States)|National Economic Council]], replacing [[Gary Cohn (investment banker)|Gary Cohn]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Haberman |first1=Maggie |last2=Kelly |first2=Kate |last3=Tankersley |first3=Jim |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/14/business/larry-kudlow-trump-national-economic-council.html |title=Trump Picks CNBC's Larry Kudlow as Top Economic Adviser |date=March 14, 2018 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Thursday, '''March 15''' | * The Trump administration uses the [[Countering America's Adversaries Through Sanctions Act]] to impose financial sanctions on the 13 Russian government hackers and spy agencies indicted in the [[Special Counsel investigation (2017–present)|Special Counsel investigation]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Sheth |first=Sonam |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/trump-new-russia-sanctions-election-meddling-cyber-attacks-2018-3 |title=Trump administration announces new sanctions on Russians charged in the Mueller investigation |work=Business Insider |date=March 15, 2018 |accessdate=March 15, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''March 16''' | *[[Andrew McCabe]], former acting director of the FBI who was due to retire with benefits in two days, was fired from the FBI by Attorney General [[Jeff Sessions]] on the recommendation of FBI disciplinary officials for "lack of candor".<ref>{{cite He did it anyway.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/trumps-national-security-advisers-warned-him-not-to-congratulate-putin-he-did-it-anyway/2018/03/20/22738ebc-2c68-11e8-8ad6-fbc50284fce8_story.html|website=www.washingtonpost.com|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=March 21, 2018}}</ref> *President Trump meets with Crown Prince [[Mohammad bin Salman]] of [[Saudi Arabia]] in the Oval Office.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Landler|first1=Mark|title=Saudi Prince's White House Visit Reinforces Trump's Commitment to Heir Apparent|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/20/us/politics/saudi-crown-prince-arrives-at-white-house-to-meet-with-trump.html|work=The New York Times|accessdate=March 22, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Thursday, '''March 22''' | * [[H.R. McMaster]] resigns as National Security Adviser and [[John R. Bolton|John Bolton]], a former ambassador to the United Nations, is named to succeed him.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Landler|first1=Mark|last2=Davis|first2=Julie|last3=Baker|first3=Peter|title=McMaster to Resign as National Security Adviser, and Will Be Replaced by John Bolton|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/03/22/us/politics/hr-mcmaster-trump-bolton.html|website=www.nytimes.com|publisher=New York Times|accessdate=March 22, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Friday, '''March 23''' | * The White House issues a memorandum on [[Jim Mattis]]'s recommended military policies, which state that [[Transgender personnel in the United States military|transgender personnel]] are "disqualified from military service except under limited circumstances."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bowden |first1=John |last2=Anapol |first2=Avery |url=http://thehill.com/homenews/administration/380050-trump-bans-most-transgender-americans-from-serving-in-the-military |title=Trump moves to ban most transgender people from serving in military |date=March 23, 2018 |work=The Hill |accessdate=March 24, 2018}}</ref> *The U.S. charges and sanctions nine Iranians and the Iranian company Mabna Institute for hacking and attempting to hack hundreds of universities [[Cyberwarfare in Iran|on behalf of the Iranian government]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Volz |first=Dustin |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-iran/u-s-charges-sanctions-iranians-for-global-cyber-attacks-on-behalf-of-tehran-idUSKBN1GZ22K |title=U.S. charges, sanctions Iranians for global cyber attacks on behalf of Tehran |publisher=Reuters |date=March 23, 2018 |accessdate=March 24, 2018}}</ref> | |- style="background:white;" | colspan="3" |
==== Week 62 ==== |- | Monday, '''March 26''' | *The White House announces the expulsion of 60 Russian diplomats.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Diamond|first1=Jeremy|last2=Malloy|first2=Allie|last3=Dewan|first3=Angela|title=Trump expelling 60 Russian diplomats in wake of UK nerve agent attack|url=https://www.cnn.com/2018/03/26/politics/us-expel-russian-diplomats/index.html|website=www.cnn.com|publisher=CNN|accessdate=March 28, 2018}}</ref> | |- | Wednesday, '''March 28''' | *President Trump fires Secretary of Veteran Affairs [[David Shulkin]] and nominates White House doctor [[Ronny L.
